title: 104_hr4110
content: The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" is cited as the short title. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on Health Insurance Availability for Children. Subtitle L--Health Insurance Availability for Children, CHAPTER 101--HEALTH INSURANCE AVAILABILITY FOR CHILDREN, Sec. 9901 - Excise tax on failure to meet requirement of access to coverage, Sec. 9902 - Requirement of access to coverage, Sec. 9903 - Definitions. Imposition of a tax on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements. The tax amount is 25 percent of each premium received for group health plan failures. The tax imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements is 25 percent of each premium received. For self-insured plans, the cost of coverage is treated as the premium received. The tax imposed on insurers offering individual health insurance coverage is 25 percent of the total premiums paid for the plan year in which the failure occurs. No tax is imposed if the failure is not discovered through reasonable diligence. No tax will be imposed on any failure if it is established that the persons involved did not know, or could not have known with reasonable diligence, about the failure. Additionally, no tax will be imposed if the failure is corrected within 30 days and was due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect. If a failure to comply with tax regulations is due to reasonable cause and corrected within 30 days of discovery, the Secretary may waive part or all of the tax imposed. The tax imposed may be waived if payment is excessive relative to the failure. This section does not apply to governmental or church plans. Liability for the tax falls on the responsible party, such as the group health plan. The tax imposed on a group health plan falls on the plan, while the tax imposed on an insurer offering health insurance coverage falls on the insurer. SEC. 9902 requires access to coverage. Each group health plan must offer qualifying coverage for qualifying young dependents of participants. The offer should be made when a person first becomes a qualifying young dependent and annually thereafter. Similarly, insurers in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age. Insurance coverage in the individual market must provide qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age, residing in the United States, and a citizen or national of the United States. Qualifying coverage includes health care benefits without limitations based on pre-existing conditions or waiting periods. Insurance coverage in the individual market must provide qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age, residing in the United States, and a citizen or national of the United States. Qualifying coverage includes health care benefits without any waiting period for Medicare benefits under parts A and B of title XVIII of the Social Security Act, or benefits determined to be actuarially equivalent to such benefits. The coinsurance for part B benefits should not exceed the lesser of $10 or 10 percent of the recognized payment amount for an item or service. Payment for well child care benefits includes newborn and well-baby care without deductibles, coinsurance, or copayments. The well child care benefits cover newborn and well-baby care, pediatrician services for high-risk deliveries, routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, will establish a periodicity schedule for well child care services to reflect the appropriate frequency for healthy children. Managed care is permitted without limiting provider options. Managed care is allowed without limiting provider options for the benefits described in the section. A "qualifying young dependent" is defined as an individual under 21 years old, residing in the US, a citizen or national (or alien permanently residing in the US under color of law), and a dependent as defined in section 152. "SEC. 9903. DEFINITIONS." "In this chapter, the term 'group health plan' is defined as per section 5000(b)(1) with an exception for plans that only offer coverage described in paragraph (2)(B). 'Health insurance coverage' refers to benefits for medical care under any hospital or medical service policy or plan." The term 'group health plan' excludes coverage under certain policies, certificates, or contracts offered by insurers or health maintenance organizations. The curr_chunk discusses various types of supplemental health coverage, including vision, disability income, long-term care, nursing home care, dental, on-site medical clinics, and employee assistance programs. It also mentions Medicare supplemental health insurance and coverage issued as a supplement to liability insurance. The curr_chunk discusses different types of supplemental health coverage, including liability insurance supplements, general liability insurance, automobile liability insurance, workers' compensation insurance, automobile medical-payment insurance, specified disease or illness coverage, and hospital or fixed indemnity. The curr_chunk discusses supplemental health coverage for specified diseases or illnesses, hospital or fixed indemnity insurance, short-term limited duration insurance, and other comparable coverage as specified in regulations. The curr_chunk defines a health maintenance organization as a federally qualified organization under the Public Health Service Act, recognized under State law, or regulated for solvency in the same manner as a health maintenance organization under State law. The curr_chunk defines an insurer as an insurance company, service, or organization licensed to do business in a State and subject to State insurance regulations. The curr_chunk further defines terms related to the individual market for health insurance coverage, excluding coverage offered only through association affiliation. The curr_chunk clarifies definitions for beneficiaries and participants in relation to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, based on association affiliation. Subtitle L. Health Insurance Availability for Children. The requirement of section 9902 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall take effect on January 1, 1998, and apply to coverage offered on or after that date. Additionally, a refundable tax credit is provided for the purchase of health coverage for children. A refundable tax credit is provided for the purchase of health coverage for children under section 35 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A refundable tax credit is available for individuals to offset 80% of qualified health premiums paid in a taxable year. The credit is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. The term 'tax liability' refers to the excess of the tax imposed for the taxable year and the taxpayer's social security taxes, minus the credit allowed under section 32. The term 'social security taxes' refers to the taxes imposed on amounts received by the taxpayer during the calendar year, including one-half of the taxes imposed by sections 3101 and 3201(a). The taxpayer can receive a special refund of social security taxes, including one-half of the taxes on self-employment income and amounts received during the taxable year. The taxpayer may receive a special refund of social security taxes, excluding taxes eligible for a special refund under section 6413(c) and amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates equivalent to the taxes mentioned. The taxpayer may receive a special refund of social security taxes, excluding taxes eligible for a special refund under section 6413(c) and amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates equivalent to the taxes mentioned. Definitions for terms like qualified health premium, health coverage, and qualifying young dependent are provided for this section. The section includes qualifying coverage and defines the term 'qualifying young dependent'. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1997.
